title: 108_hr2592
content: The "Healthy America Act" is the short title of this legislation. Congress acknowledges the importance of improving the nation's diet to combat diseases like coronary heart disease, cancer, stroke, and diabetes. It is crucial to consume a healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables to promote health and prevent chronic illnesses. However, most children and adults do not meet the recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables. The Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) aims to improve nutrition for needy Americans by providing fruits and vegetables to at-risk populations. To promote improved nutrition for needy Americans, including women, infants, children, and students, by revising Federal nutrition programs to incorporate a greater role for fruits, vegetables, and 100 percent juice products. This includes extending, expanding, and enhancing Federal nutrition policies to encourage consumption of fruits, vegetables, and juices for health promotion and disease prevention. Developing nutrition policies to increase awareness of the benefits of fruits and vegetables in disease prevention and health promotion is also a key goal. To increase the Federal government's investment in nutrition programs to prioritize fruits and vegetables for the health promotion and disease prevention of needy Americans. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "fruit and vegetables" refers to produce meeting specific guidelines for health programs. The term "juice" refers to 100 percent juice without added fat or sugar. SEC. 4. SCHOOL BREAKFAST PROGRAM. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to require schools in the school breakfast program to offer fruits and 100 percent juices. The Commodities Purchase Program for Breakfasts now includes a provision for the value of donated foods or cash payments to be 5 cents for the school breakfast program. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to include a provision for the value of donated foods or cash payments to be 5 cents for the school breakfast program. A conforming amendment is made to the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF FRUIT AND VEGETABLE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 18(g) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to establish a Fruit and Vegetable Pilot Program. The program provides free fresh and dried fruits, as well as fresh vegetables to students in selected schools and service institutions during the school day. The Fruit and Vegetable Pilot Program provides free fresh and dried fruits, as well as fresh vegetables to children in selected schools and service institutions. Participating schools must publicize the availability of free fruits and vegetables and can use a portion of funds for administrative expenses. The Secretary will report on the results of the pilot program to the House of Representatives and Senate committees by May 1, 2007. Up to $75,000,000 from section 32 funds will be used annually, with a limit of 10 percent for subsequent years. The Healthy Foods for Healthy Kids Initiative Grant Program is established. The Healthy Foods for Healthy Kids Initiative Grant Program, established under Section 18 of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act, provides grants to school districts for projects that increase the availability and consumption of fruits and vegetables. The program, in collaboration with the National 5 A Day for Better Health program, aims to support innovative projects that enhance infrastructure for procurement, delivery, and storage efforts. The Healthy Foods for Healthy Kids Initiative Grant Program aims to enhance offerings of fruits and vegetables in school districts through various methods such as salad bars, fruit cups, and school garden projects to promote fruit and vegetable intake, provide training for food service personnel, and educate children on nutrition concepts. The Healthy Foods for Healthy Kids Initiative Grant Program aims to promote healthier food choices for children. The Secretary will evaluate the program's results and submit a report to relevant committees. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 through 2009. SEC. 7 amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to ensure that summer food service programs include fruits, vegetables, and 100 percent juices. SEC. 8 focuses on improving and modernizing requirements under the Women, Infants, and Children Program. The Secretary will update and improve the nutritional standards of the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children. The program will re-evaluate and revise food package requirements every 10 years, allow access to fresh fruits and vegetables, permit the purchase of non-concentrated juices, and revise packaging requirements to include modern options like plastic and carton containers. The Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children will update nutritional standards, allow access to fresh fruits and vegetables, permit purchase of generic branded produce, and focus on promoting fruit and vegetable consumption in nutrition education efforts. SEC. 9. Department of Defense increases funding for fresh fruits and vegetables to $100,000,000. SEC. 10. Fruit and vegetable research agenda. The Secretary of Agriculture will develop a research agenda for fruits and vegetables to promote intake among children and prevent chronic diseases. Coordination with various stakeholders is required, including the produce industry and health organizations. Research goals include studying the impact of increased fruit and vegetable consumption on chronic diseases like obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. The research agenda for fruits and vegetables aims to promote intake among children and prevent chronic diseases. This includes studying the impact of increased consumption on diseases like obesity, diabetes, and heart disease, as well as developing behavior-based interventions and identifying influences on food choices. The Secretary appoints a national 5 A Day coordinator and 7 regional coordinators to promote fruit and vegetable consumption. Additionally, a report on the commodity purchasing program is required. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report on commodity purchasing practices aligning with Dietary Guidelines to specified committees within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Act emphasizes state and local partnerships. The Secretary of Agriculture should establish partnerships with State departments of agriculture, health departments, education departments, and other organizations to improve access to fresh fruits and vegetables in schools and nutrition programs.
